title: The tactical benefits Kieran Tierney and Hector Bellerin will offer Unai Emery's Arsenal
text:
Arsenal and Unai Emery have been waiting on the return of full-backs Hector Bellerin and Kieran Tierney since the start of the season, and the international break bought the pair time in their quest to build fitness.

The sight of Bellerin and Tierney in Premier League action, potentially at Sheffield United on Monday, will be a bookmark in Arsenal's season and leave Emery with no excuses for not achieving Champions League qualification.

Bellerin and Tierney have already provided assists in cup appearances, and their threatening delivery from the flanks is the most obvious improvement they promise. Emery relied on overlapping full-backs or wing-backs for chance creation last season.

However, there are potentially more subtle, structural benefits on offer for Emery. A curious sight this season has been Arsenal's midfielders strung across the pitch, often in a flat three, with the two players either side of Granit Xhaka tasked with defending the flanks.

None of Ainsley Maitland-Niles, Sead Kolasinac or Calum Chambers are natural full-backs, so the urge to protect them is an understandable coaching instinct. Arsenal also have a £72 million wide forward in Nicolas Pepe on the right, who Emery seems keen not to overburden defensively.
